Award.AwardTitle: Reinvestment in Physics Research Center at Hampton University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

This project involves the renovation of sections of the Graduate Physics Research Center (GPRC), a 7,000 sq ft building used for physics research and research training.

The renovated facility will be used for research in particle physics and optics, including laser crystal development, and the study of the optical properties of nanoscale materials. The research in high-energy physics will include analyses of data from the ATLAS detector that forms part of the Large Hadron Collider experiment, and from the MINERvA neutrino scattering experiment at Fermilab.

In addition to providing infrastructure for faculty research, the renovated labs will provide infrastructure for research training of undergraduates and graduate students from a student body that is predominantly composed of members groups that are under-represented in science and engineering. A better facility will be more conducive to attracting students to modern research. The renovated laboratories will also be used to provide research experiences for undergraduates from other institutions (through a Research Experiences for Undergraduates program) and for school-teachers (through Hampton University?s Research Experiences for Teachers program).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Completed Graduate Physics Research Center Project Overview

  • Renovation of existing research areas at Hampton University to support research that can address the challenges of the 21st century
  • The broader impact of the project will come from the fact that most undergraduates and graduates students at Hampton are African American
  • The intellectual merit comes from the variety of research and research training activities pursued in the GPRC, including fluorescent spectroscopy and laser crystal development study of optical properties of nano-scale materials, detector development, and simulation of particle physics processes and detectors and analysis of data from these detectors (ATLAS and MINERvA)



The Project Elements


  • Laboratory-grade climate control
  • Upgraded electrical supply
  • Improvements in laboratory environment, health, and safety arrangements, including fume hoods for materials preparation
  • A general-purpose chiller system
  • Improved energy efficiency of the building, as far as changes to laboratories can contribute
  • Improved fiber pathways to the areas being renovated; and other minor improvements



The major goal of the project was to renovate the existing areas at Hampton University to support research that can address the challenges of the 21st Century. Hampton University is an HBCU that also have a strong graduate programs including, Physics Ph.D. and Master’s programs.

The targeted research areas are in the Graduate Physics Research Center (GPRC), a 7,000 sq ft building used entirely for physics research and research training. The GPRC supports experimental research for the Advanced Center for Laser Science and Spectroscopy (ACLASS, PHY-1137747), a CREST Center for Laser Science and Spectroscopy (CLaSS, HRD-0630372), a program for Nanoscience Transforming STEM Education (HRD-1238838), the ATLAS experiment at the CERN LHC (PHY-0610275), and the Particle Physics Computing Facility (PPCF, PHY-619182). The Particle Physics Computing Facility is open to multiple education and research projects on campus and serves other research areas as in nuclear physics (PHY-1002644, PHY-1307415, PHY-1207672) with the researchers from MINERvA experiment. The bulk of research and training in GPRC is NSF-funded.

The NSF sponsored renovations and improvements that have broadened Hampton University Research capabilities to enhance five distinct aspects: (a) Energy efficiency and architectural changes. Improved insulation will reduce energy demand. New ceilings tiles facilitate maintenance and repairs without affecting insulation. New windows with smaller footprints allow natural sunlight while minimizing the heat exchange. Windows in the over the ceiling area were eliminated and ventilation grids were installed where they were needed. Roof replacement stopped water leaks and exposure to weather elements. (b) Electrical power capacity was increased by 50%. The increase of capacity was accompanied with an upgrade of electrical distribution circuitry and independent electrical panels to each lab. (c) Lab support through upgraded electrical services, independent HVAC systems in each lab and provision of cooled water for high power lasers (d) Broadband network connections were implemented to other National Sciences buildings and the Physics Department research locations within the University. New fiber installation was installed to expand the external high-speed network infrastructure for the existing computing facility. (e) Lab safety: a new waterless fire suppression system (FM-200) was installed in research areas and the while fire alert and suppression system was updated.
